overview.name: Northern White Cedar
overview.description: "The principal kinds of wood used for poles in the United States are as follows: Northern white cedar, found most abundantly in the northern parts of Michigan, Wisconsin, and Minnesota, and in smaller quantities in the territory in the same latitude extending eastward through Ontario and the northern part of Maine to the Atlantic Coast... Northern white cedar is the most largely used, and for a great many years has furnished the principal supply of poles.

overview.name: Western Red Cedar
overview.description: "The principal kinds of wood used for poles in the United States are as follows: ..Western red cedar, an upland produet found growing in Idaho, Washington, Oregon, Montana, and British Columbia.

overview.name: Chesnut
overview.description: "The principal kinds of wood used for poles in the United States are as follows: ..Chestnut, largely used in the East, and found in the Atlantic Coast states from Massachusetts to North Carolina, inclusive, and in parts of Tennessee, Kentucky, Pennsylvania, Ohio, and Indiana.

overview.name: Yellow Pine
overview.description: "The principal kinds of wood used for poles in the United States are as follows: ..Yellow pine and juniper are used to some small extent throughout the South, where they are found.
